head.title: Quaker Oats Said to Refuse PepsiCo Bid

hedline.hl1: Quaker Oats Said to Refuse PepsiCo Bid

body.head.byline: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and GREG WINTER

abstract.p: Quaker Oats Co informally rejects $13.7 billion offer to be acquired by PepsiCo Inc; chart (M)

block.p: The Quaker Oats Company informally rejected a $13.7 billion offer to be acquired by PepsiCo yesterday, according to executives close to the negotiations. Executives of the two consumer products giants had been meeting privately to discuss a sale, but could not agree on a price.

It is unclear whether the talks will resume. An executive close to PepsiCo suggested that the company would most likely abandon its attempt to take over Quaker Oats, whose brands include Rice-a-Roni, Aunt Jemima, Cap'n Crunch and Gatorade, the product that Pepsi most coveted because of its market dominance.

The Quaker Oats Company informally rejected a $13.7 billion offer to be acquired by PepsiCo yesterday, according to executives close to the negotiations. Executives of the two consumer products giants had been meeting privately to discuss a sale, but could not agree on a price.

It is unclear whether the talks will resume. An executive close to PepsiCo suggested that the company would most likely abandon its attempt to take over Quaker Oats, whose brands include Rice-a-Roni, Aunt Jemima, Cap'n Crunch and Gatorade, the product that Pepsi most coveted because of its market dominance.

Pepsi, which is based in Purchase, N.Y., offered 2.2 of its shares for each Quaker Oats share, the executives said. That would value Quaker's shares at $103.68, or 26 percent above yesterday's closing price, but Quaker Oats executives rejected the offer as insufficient, the executives said. Executives close to Pepsi said it was unlikely the company, the No. 2 soda maker, would return with a higher offer.
Without a deal with PespsiCo, Quaker Oats could become the target of a fierce bidding war from rival suitors like Coca-Cola, Nestle and Danone.
Shares of Quaker Oats closed yesterday at $82.25 on the New York Stock Exchange, unchanged from Wednesday. Shares of PepsiCo fell 88 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $47.13 yesterday in New York.
In addition to Pepsi Cola, PepsiCo makes Tropicana Pure Premium orange juice, Lay's and Doritos chips and Rold Gold pretzels.

It remains unclear whether PepsiCo would have kept all of Quaker Oats' product lines or sold off brands like Rice-a-Roni and Aunt Jemima. The executives hinted that some brands would certainly be auctioned off if a deal were completed.
A spokesman for PepsiCo declined to comment. A spokesman for Quaker Oats could not be reached.

The offer epitomizes PepsiCo's unbridled thrust to stake out a commanding position in the noncarbonated beverage industry, a fast-growing frontier that soft drink makers have traditionally been slow to explore but have been forced to take seriously in recent years.

At a time when soda sales in the United States are stagnant and show few signs of rejuvenation, sales of juices and sports drinks have been growing more than 8 percent a year. Gatorade, the clear leader in the field with a market share of more than 83 percent, has done even better, racing along at nearly 12 percent this year.

For months, investors have been clamoring for soft drink companies to either buy such promising juice, tea and other nonbubbly brands or develop their own. But while Coca-Cola continues to be distracted by a painful reorganization process that has included layoffs of roughly 18 percent of its work force, Pepsi is seizing every opportunity to nip at the heels of its larger rival.

Earlier this week, Pepsi announced that it had purchased a 90 percent stake in the South Beach Beverage Company, the maker of the still-small but increasingly popular SoBe juices and teas, for $370 million in cash. Coke officials had been entrenched in unsuccessful negotiations to buy a stake in the drink manufacturer for months. As soon as the talks broke down, Pepsi officials swooped in and struck a deal.

If Pepsi were to acquire Gatorade, the challenge to Coke would be far more serious. Sales of Gatorade topped $1.8 billion last year, compared with $4.4 billion for Pepsi drinks. If PepsiCo grabs it, analysts say, there will be few comparable brands in the noncarbonated segment left for Coke to acquire.
''If Pepsi does this, it's a hugely aggressive deal,'' said John Sicher, editor of Beverage Digest, an industry newsletter. ''Gatorade is a gem of a brand.''

Some analysts feel that Coke, moving cautiously to avoid conflicts with the Federal Trade Commission, has missed out on a series of acquisitions in the industry's biggest growth areas. In a $910 million deal last month, Cadbury-Schweppes bought Snapple, a brand that Quaker bought in 1994 for roughly $1.7 billion and sold for just $300 million a few years later after stifling its growth.

Without Snapple in Quaker's portfolio, a deal could be less likely to conflict with regulators should one be reached. But Pepsi does own All-Sport, a drink in the same category as Gatorade, but has been losing market share recently.

Analysts also speculate that Pepsi would be apt to sell off some of Quaker's food businesses as well, particularly in cereals, a market that has been stagnant recently and shows few signs of a turnaround.
